name: Full Moon (Buck Moon)
description: Named for deer antlers; appears golden at moonrise :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

name: Mercury greatest eastern elongation
description: Mercury at its farthest evening separation from Sun

name: Moon–Saturn conjunction
description: The Moon passes close to Saturn in the sky

name: Moon–Pleiades occultation
description: Moon temporarily hides stars of the Pleiades cluster

name: Moon–Mars conjunction
description: The Moon and Mars appear near each other after sunset

name: Southern Delta Aquariids peak
description: Steady ~25 meteors/hour shower into Aquarius :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

name: Alpha Capricornids peak
description: Produces bright fireballs, though lower rate :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

name: Perseid Meteor Shower peak
description: Bright, fast meteors at 50–100/hr—year’s best shower :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

name: Venus–Jupiter conjunction
description: Two brightest planets appear very close in dawn sky :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

name: Full Moon (Sturgeon Moon)
description: August full moon named for seasonal fish catch

name: Mercury greatest western elongation
description: Best morning visibility of Mercury apart from Sun

name: Total Lunar Eclipse
description: “Blood Moon”—Moon darkens red for ~82 min :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

name: Full Moon (Harvest Moon)
description: Full moon nearest autumnal equinox; aids late‑night harvest

name: Moon–Saturn conjunction
description: Moon and Saturn appear close in morning sky

name: Partial Solar Eclipse
description: Partial eclipse visible from parts of Oceania/Antarctica :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}

name: Saturn opposition
description: Saturn opposite Sun—brightest and best viewed :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}

name: September equinox
description: Day and night equal length; start of astronomical autumn :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}

name: Full Moon (Hunter’s Supermoon)
description: Full ‘Hunter’s Moon’ appears slightly larger/brighter :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}

name: Draconids peak
description: Minor shower radiates from Draco, visible after sunset :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}

name: Orionids peak
description: Fast meteors from Halley’s comet at ~20/hr :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

name: Jupiter opposition
description: Jupiter opposite Sun—bright and all‑night visible :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}

name: Full Moon (Beaver Supermoon)
description: Moon near perigee, brighter full ‘Beaver Moon’ :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}

name: Taurids peak
description: Slow, bright meteors; Southern Taurids active :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}

name: Leonids peak
description: Fast meteors from Leonids; ~10–15/hr :contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}

name: Uranus opposition
description: Uranus brightest for year; telescope target :contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}

name: Full Moon (Cold Supermoon)
description: Full ‘Cold Moon’ supermoon about 8% larger :contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}

name: Moon–Pleiades conjunction
description: 98% Moon passes near Pleiades cluster :contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}

name: Phoenicids peak
description: Minor shower from Phoenix; variable rates :contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}

name: Geminids peak
description: One of best showers: up to ~120/hr, colorful :contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}

name: Ursids peak
description: Minor winter shower ~5–10/hr, dark moon :contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}

name: December solstice
description: Start of winter NH / summer SH—the year’s shortest day :contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}
